name.en: Special Topics in Signal Integrity and Electromagnetic Compatibility
name.ch: 信號完整度與電磁相容專題

goal.ch: This class will cover some special topics in the field of signal integrity (SI) and electromagnetic compatibility (EMC), including transmission line theory, causality theory, macromodeling, and power integrity, as detailed in the course content below. While transmission line and power integrity are important subjects specific for SI engineers, causality and macromodeling are topics that also find broad applications in other branches of physics. The theories of these topics will be introduced in class, and students are required to complete several homework which are mostly Python-coding problems (but not exclusively). This course is not a sequel of the course Signal Integrity and Electromagnetic Compatibility of the spring semester, so students are welcome to take this course even if you have not taken the spring-semester one. Undergraduates are also welcome to take this course as long as you have studied 電磁學, 複變, and 信號與系統.

outline.ch:
1. Numerical inverse Fourier transform
2. Transmission line theory
* Exact TEM mode
* Dielectric model
* Quasi-TEM mode
* Conductor model
* TDR
* Surface roughness
* Multi-conductor line
3. Causality
* Causality theorems
* Causality assessment
* Causality enforcement
4. Macromodeling
* Rational fitting algorithms
* Recursive convolution
* Circuit synthesis
5. Power integrity
* Voltage regulator module
* PDN impedance
* PDN design and simulation

textbook.ch:
1. Stephen Hall and Howard Heck, Advanced Signal Integrity for High Speed Digital Designs, Wiley-IEEE Press, 2009. ( https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/book/5361024 ) 
2. Clayton Paul, Introduction to Electromagnetic Compatibility, Wiley, 2005. ( https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/book/10.1002/0471758159 ) Both books can be downloaded if you are within NCU‘s ip. 
3. M. Swaminathan and A. Engin, Power Integrity Modeling and Design for Semiconductors and Systems, Prentice Hall, 2008. (Available at library)
4. Eric Bogatin, Signal and Power Integrity – Simplified, 2nd ed., Prentice Hall, 2010, Ch 13. (Available at library)
5. S. Grivet-Talocia and B. Gustavsen, Passive macromodeling: Theory and applications, John Wiley ＆ Sons, 2016. (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/book/10.1002/9781119140931)

gradMethod.ch: Homework 100％, which includes: (1) about 16 homework, each accounts for about 7~12％ of the final grade, depending on the complexity of the problem; (2) homework presentation: each week we will randomly select a few students to briefly describe their homework report in class. The report of the selected students will be displayed to the whole class, and I will ask some questions for the presenters regarding their results. If the selected students are absent, they will get 0 score for that homework. Also note that the reports of all students of all homework will be open for every one in class to view, in the eeclass system.
